description.narrative: CSSP is a joint Donor Pooled Funding of Civil Society Organisations. Currently, It is aimed at building the capacity of Civil Societies to respond to local needs. Currently, it is funded by Irish Aid, DfID and the Netherlands. Sweden is joining the programme in 2012.

CSSP is a joint Donor Pooled Funding of Civil Society Organisations. Currently, it is funded by Irish Aid, DfID and the Netherlands. It is aimed at building the capacity of Civil Societies to respond to local needs. Currently, it is funded by Irish Aid, DfID and the Netherlands. Sweden is joining the programme in 2012.

The objective of the CSSP are as follows: 1. Critical mass of civil society organisations which have the capability to: i) respond to development priorities determined by poor women, men, girls and boys - especially those in 'hard to reach' categories, and ii) operate as robust, accountable and legitimate organisations. 2. More civil society organisations which have the capacity to dialogue, and relate with, a range of different constituencies and stakeholders. 3. Mutual accountability for efficient and effective performance of the different actors which comprise the CSSP delivery mechanism: the Development Partners individually and as part of the CSSP Management Board (CMB) and Programme Steering Committee (PSC) including its sub-groups, the Lead Development Partner (LDP) and the Management Agent (MA) and CSSP team.

description.narrative: 1. Critical mass of CSOs The CSSP’s initial calls for proposals and assessments were structured in a manner that aided the selection of larger, more mature and financially stable organizations working on service delivery. The CSSP then enabled many of these organizations to provide sub-grants to smaller CSOs and work collaboratively with them, which served to significantly increase the number of grants given and CSOs reached. In total, 514 organizations received a CSSP grant which is a sizable proportion of CSOs working in Ethiopia. CSSP was effective in enabling CSOs to reach hard to reach groups and touch hard to reach issues. However, given the short duration and small size of the grants, many CSOs had to stop the work they were doing and fell short of making the difference envisaged. 2. Capacity Development The CSSP defined seven areas of capacity development for CSOs: one that supported the internal strengthening of CSOs and six areas that supported relations with external stakeholders such as government, donors, other CSOs and communities. The CSSP team worked on two of the seven areas: internal strengthening of CSOs and CSO-CSO engagement. These inputs were appreciated and valued. However, the other areas are conspicuous by their absence in implementation, in the CSSP Operations Manual and in the CSSP budgets and monitoring systems. It appears that no attempt was made to implement these five areas of capacity building that are central to programme success. 3. Mutual accountabilityAs this program was a multi-donor consortium led by the UK, the initial systems in place for implementation, monitoring and evaluation took several changes to get to a form that could sustain itself. The implementation challenges that arose from the complexity of the structure of the CSSP mechanism itself was one valuable lesson that led to Donors to focus more on a leaner, more simpler structure for the smooth execution of activities. However, it goes without saying that various donors coming to fund this program was on its on an achievement worth noting as this is an important program that can easily be said was ahead of its time for reasons spelt out earlier.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
